channel.title: Combined Politepol Feed
channel.description: Merged feed from multiple Politepol sources

item.title: India turns highway into runway for emergency landing near China border. Why this matters
Spicing it up: What are vinegar Valentine cards?
Who is Nikhil Gupta, who has pleaded guilty in the Pannun assassination plot?
This Week in Explainers: Is the US mulling ending the H1-B visa programme?
Iran reinforces entrances at Pickaxe Mountain amid US tensions. Why does this matter?
Seva Teerth: How PM Modi’s new office stands apart from South Block
How Bangladesh polls prick the ‘Gen Z revolution’ bubble and leave students in the lurch
item.description: Protesting students gathered on the streets in pursuit of true democracy but ended up as puppets for the designs of the deep state

item.title: Why Trump is rebuffing Netanyahu’s push for a tougher stance on Iran
item.description: The US president has stated that reaching a diplomatic deal with Iran is his ‘preference’

item.title: Bangladesh polls: People choose stability over chaos, but Dhaka’s real test begins
item.description: The verdict is not a triumph of the Bangladesh Nationalist Party alone. It is a collective signal that governance matters more than agitation, and that radical rhetoric does not substitute for administrative competence

item.title: When graffiti becomes history: Indian imprints in the land of Pharaohs and beyond
item.description: While ancient Indian graffiti in Egypt may be in the news right now, historical graffiti are not rare either in India or elsewhere in the world

item.title: How Saudi Arabia’s embrace of ‘Axis of Ikhwan’ shatters the IMEC dream
item.description: Mohammed Bin Salman might keep the illusion of participation open—all the better to play into the wishful thinking of the West that does not want to acknowledge the loss of Saudi Arabia—but India should be under no illusion

item.title: Dealing with China: Why trade and Kailash Yatra should be India’s opening move before LAC settlement
item.description: A simpler first step for an India-China reset could be to reopen the frontiers as they were in the 1950s, particularly for trade and the Kailash-Manasarovar pilgrimage, following the centuries-old tradition
